awd_titl_txt: CI-EN: Enhancement of a Large-scale Multiagent Simulation Tool
awd_abstract_narration:
An agent-based simulation is a software simulation of many independent actors (people, robots, animals, companies, etc.) interacting in complex ways.  For example, one might build a simulation of a swarm of ants, a school of fish, a large group of robots collectively building a house, a city of people under siege by a large medieval army, or the spread of urban legends over a social network. These kinds of simulations are used for everything from building software for swarms of delivery robots, to understanding the spread of disease in third-world slums, to predicting the impact of climate change on human migration patterns.  Similarly, these simulations help researchers and policy makers in engineering and robotics, in artificial intelligence, and in the biological and social sciences.  Such simulations can get very large, with large numbers of actors.  This project involves building a software tool to assist in the development of large-scale agent-based simulations spread over potentially many separate computers, and to make it easy for them to place their agents in simulated locations on the Earth.  At the same time the tool will be easy to use for high school and undergraduate students.

The project will develop a distributed agent-based modeling tool for constructing large simulations of swarms and groups of agents.  The project enhances an existing, successful open-source Java multiagent simulation library called MASON.  MASON is designed to run on a single machine; but the enhanced version will also allow distribution over many machines.  The enhanced tool will also include facilities for embedding agents in geographical information systems (GIS), model optimization and automation, interfaces for alternative programming languages targeting the Java Virtual Machine, statistics facilities, internal testing and verification, and integration with software tools.  The enhancement will not only provide a distributed simulation facility for researchers in the social sciences, biology, and engineering, but will also improve on MASON's graphical interface and language facilities to make it easier to use as a teaching tool.

por.por_cntn:
Science and engienering fields such as economics, anthropology, political science, population biology, epidemiology, and multirobotics all have an item in common: they study large numbers of actors (companies, businesses, individual people, organisms, robots) interacting with one another and giving rise to complex interrelationships and trends.  For example, scientists might simulate the rise of trade along the Silk Road, or die-offs of millions of coral in the Great Reef. These areas often benefit from simulations of these interactions among many actors: these simulations are called "agent-based models".  The problem is that, to simulate ever larger number of actors, agent-based models are growing too large to fit in a single computer.

MASON is a free, open source, high-performance agent-based modeling toolkit written in Java, and which is widely used in these fields. It is designed to simulate and visualize large agent-based models on single computers. While MASON has a strong reputation for large models in a single computer, these fields are now demanding even larger models.  In this NSF project we developed a version of MASON in which a single computer can be distributed across a large number of computers in order to make possible much larger models for the benefit of these fields.

MASON also sports an extensive facility for using Geographial Information System (or GIS) data to model actors in the physical world: such as modeling vehicles along a street in Chicago, or students walking along paths at a university.  In thie project we developed major improvements to this facility, including massively distributed versions GIS modeling over large numbers of computers.

One of the big challenges in developing large and complex agent-based models is that they often contain a great many variables whose values are unknown to the modeler.  For example, what should be the behavior of each trader be in a Silk Road simulation?  Traditionally these variables were tuned by hand to calibrate the model, but this can now be too costly.  We developed a new method to use large-scale stochastic optimization algorithms to automatically calibrate variables in models of this kind.

Finally, we have developed a new architecture which combines agent-based modeling and "discrete event simulation", a related technique used to simulate factory floor flows, supply chains, transportation networks, and so on.  This can be used, for example, to study the impact of spreads of diseases in a population on the stress points in a medical supply chain.  These topics are particularly apropos given the failures of global supply chains during the COVID period here in the US and elsewhere in the world.

Massively distributed agent-based simulation of this kind has the potential to greatly enhance many fields in the social sciences, biology, and computer sciences, among others: and these fields in turn touch on critical areas in society, from the spread of diseases to the impacts of supply chains on the economics of the country.
